questions.question: What pulmonary defense mechanism propels a mucous blanket that entraps particles moving toward the oropharynx?
questions.rationale: Cilia beat rhythmically to move mucus and trapped particles toward the oropharynx.

questions.question: Which term is used to identify the movement of gas and air into and out of the lungs?
questions.rationale: Ventilation refers to movement of air into and out of the lungs.

questions.question: When an individual aspirates food particles, where would the nurse expect to hear decreased or absent breath sounds?
questions.rationale: Right mainstem bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical.

questions.question: Aspiration is most likely to occur in the right mainstem bronchus because it:
options: Is narrower than the left bronchus
Comes into contact with food and drink first
Is located at the bronchial bifurcation
questions.rationale: Right bronchus anatomy favors aspiration.

questions.question: Air passage among alveoli is collateral and evenly distributed because of which structures?
questions.rationale: Pores of Kohn allow airflow between alveoli.

questions.question: Where in the lungs does gas exchange occur?
questions.rationale: Gas exchange occurs at the alveolocapillary membrane.

questions.question: Surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells facilitates alveolar distention and ventilation by which mechanism?
questions.rationale: Surfactant decreases surface tension.

questions.question: Which part of the brainstem provides the basic automatic rhythm of respiration by sending efferent impulses to the diaphragm and intercostal muscles?
questions.rationale: DRG provides basic automatic rhythm of respiration.

questions.question: Which structures secrete surfactant?
questions.rationale: Type II alveolar cells secrete surfactant.

questions.question: Which structure is not associated with lymphatic vessels?
questions.rationale: Acinus is not associated with lymphatic vessels.

questions.question: Which describes the pressure in the pleural space?
questions.rationale: Pleural pressure is below atmospheric.

questions.question: The adequacy of alveolar ventilation is assessed best by monitoring which mechanism?
questions.rationale: Arterial blood gas best assesses alveolar ventilation.

questions.question: Which normal physiologic change occurs in the aging pulmonary system?
questions.rationale: Aging causes stiffening of the chest wall.

questions.question: How is most oxygen in the blood transported?
questions.rationale: Most oxygen is transported bound to hemoglobin.

questions.question: Stretch receptors and peripheral chemoreceptors send afferent impulses to which brain location?
questions.rationale: Afferent impulses go to the DRG in the medulla.

questions.question: Which substances cause airway epithelium to constrict?
questions.rationale: Histamine and prostaglandin cause airway constriction.

questions.question: If a patient develops acidosis, what shift in hemoglobin-oxygen dissociation is expected?
questions.rationale: Acidosis causes a right shift, releasing more O₂.

questions.question: How is most carbon dioxide (CO₂) in the blood transported?
questions.rationale: Most CO₂ is transported as bicarbonate.

questions.question: The sternocleidomastoid and scalene muscles are classified as:
questions.rationale: These are accessory inspiratory muscles.

questions.question: An increase in surface tension caused by decreased surfactant results in:
questions.rationale: Decreased surfactant increases alveolar fluid.

questions.question: Decreased lung compliance means the lungs are:
questions.rationale: Decreased compliance means lungs are difficult to inflate.

questions.question: The lung is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system via which nerve?
questions.rationale: The vagus nerve innervates the lung.

questions.question: What event is characteristic of Zone 1 of lung function?
questions.rationale: Zone 1: alveolar pressure exceeds arterial pressure.

questions.question: Hyperventilation with CO₂ retention stimulates which receptors?
questions.rationale: Central chemoreceptors are stimulated by CO₂ retention.

questions.question: Most important cause of pulmonary artery constriction?
questions.rationale: Low alveolar PO₂ is the most important cause.

questions.question: Where does the tracheal bifurcation occur?
questions.rationale: Tracheal bifurcation occurs at the carina.

questions.question: At what PaO₂ do peripheral chemoreceptors stimulate ventilation?
questions.rationale: Peripheral chemoreceptors stimulate ventilation at PaO₂ <60 mmHg.

questions.question: Which receptors are located in smooth muscles of airways?
questions.rationale: Stretch receptors are located in airway smooth muscle.

questions.question: Which receptors are located near the respiratory center?
questions.rationale: Central chemoreceptors are near the respiratory center.

questions.question: Which receptors are in aortic bodies and carotids?
questions.rationale: Peripheral chemoreceptors are in aortic bodies and carotids.

questions.question: Purpose of spirometry measurement?
questions.rationale: Spirometry measures pH and gas concentrations.

questions.question: Which structures are upper conducting airways? (Select all that apply)
questions.rationale: Oropharynx and nasopharynx are upper conducting airways.

questions.question: Regarding remodeling, which are true? (Select all that apply)
questions.rationale: Remodeling involves airway walls, scarring/thickening, permanent change, and causes pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: What are the effects of aging on the pulmonary system? (Select all that apply)
questions.rationale: Aging causes decreased compliance, recoil, ventilatory reserve, and PaO₂.

questions.question: Match the receptor with its function: Irritant receptors, Stretch receptors, J-receptors, Peripheral chemoreceptors, Central chemoreceptors
questions.rationale: A. Irritant receptors → Rapid shallow breathing; B. Stretch receptors → Hering-Breuer reflex; C. J-receptors → Initiates cough reflex; D. Peripheral chemoreceptors → Monitor PaO₂/CO₂, pH; E. Central chemoreceptors → Monitor CSF pH.
